newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila says reverses U.S. sugar quota export ban.
newsitem.headline: Manila says reverses U.S. sugar quota export ban.

text.p: The Philippine Sugar Board reversed on Friday its earlier decision not to take up the additional sugar export quota to the United States, a senior official said.

Sugar Regulatory Administration chief Wilson Gamboa said the board, chaired by Agriculture Secretary Salvador Escudero, approved in a meeting early on Friday to fill up the additional 27,000 tonnes in the U.S. quota given last May 12.
The board informed the United States on May 8 that Manila did not want to export more sugar during the crop year 1996/1997 (Sept/Aug) due to a projected shortfall in the domestic supply.
Gamboa said in a statement the board withdrew its earlier decision following a better-than-expected harvest this year.
The additional sugar quota was given to the Philippines on May 12. It brings to 273,991 tonnes the total quota given by the United States to the Philippines.
Escudero said in a news conference the 20,000 tonnes of sugar will come from farmers, while the remaining 7,000 tonnes will be sourced from the stocks of state-owned National Food Authority (NFA).
NFA bought around 260,000 tonnes of domestic raw sugar as part of its programme to support local prices early this year.
Under the quota system, the US buys sugar from selected countries at a premium over marker prices.
Gamboa said the Philippines accounts for 13.5 percent of the total US sugar quota.
